title: What's News --  Business & Finance
text:
U.S. stock indexes fell and bond yields slipped, while oil prices rose above $100 to their highest level since 2014, as Russia's invasion of Ukraine continued to whipsaw through markets. The S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq slid 1.5%, 1.8% and 1.6%, respectively.

---

Exxon Mobil said it is halting operations at a multibillion-dollar oil and gas project in Russia and will make no further investments in the country.

The U.S. and other major oil-consuming nations said they would release 60 million barrels of oil from their emergency stockpiles.

Apple, Ford, Boeing and Dell joined the roster of companies retreating from Russia, while other global businesses, including VW, warned of further supply disruptions.

---

The first two series of the MLB regular season have been canceled after owners and locked-out players failed to agree on a new labor contract ahead of a management-imposed deadline.

---

The Biden administration said it is realigning its trade policy toward China, looking at all existing tools and potentially new ones to combat Beijing's state-led nonmarket practices.

---

Target's sales rose in the most recent quarter, helped by stronger traffic in the company's stores through the holiday season and growth across its merchandise categories.

---

The Bank of Canada is expected to raise its benchmark interest rate on Wednesday in the face of historically high inflation.
